{{Infobox Military Structure |name= Camp Foster |location= [[Okinawa Island]], [[Japan]] |image= [[File:CampFosterCommCenter.png|300px]] |caption= The community center at Camp Foster. |type= Military base |built= |materials= |used= |controlledby= [[United States Marine Corps|USMC]] |garrison= |commanders= |battles= }} '''Camp Foster''', formerly known as '''Camp Zukeran''' ({{lang-ja|キャンプ瑞慶覧}}) is a [[United States Marine Corps]] camp located in [[Ginowan]] City with portions overlapping into [[Okinawa, Okinawa|Okinawa City]], [[Chatan, Okinawa|Chatan town]] and [[Kitanakagusuku, Okinawa|Kitanakagusuku village]] in the [[Okinawa Prefecture|Japanese prefecture]] of [[Okinawa Island]]. It is part of the [[Marine Corps Base Camp Smedley D. Butler]] complex.
==Description== {{unreferenced section|date=March 2014}}Camp Foster a [[United States Marine Corps]] camp located in [[Ginowan]] City. Some of its portions overlap with [[Okinawa, Okinawa|Okinawa City]], [[Chatan, Okinawa|Chatan town]] and [[Kitanakagusuku, Okinawa|Kitanakagusuku village]] in the [[Okinawa Prefecture|Japanese prefecture]] of [[Okinawa Island]]. It houses the headquarters of [[Marine Corps Base Camp Smedley D. Butler|Marine Corps Base Butler]], [[Marine Corps Installations Pacific]] and the Okinawa Area Field Office of [[United States Forces Japan]]. It was named after the [[Medal of Honor]] recipient PFC [[William A. Foster]].
Among its amenities are a large exchange with an adjacent food court, bowling alley, skate park, performing arts center and movie theater. The base operates three schools: Zukeran and Killin elementary schools and [[Kubasaki High School]]. The base's housing units include Kishaba, [[Chatan, Japan|Chatan]], [[Futenma]], Plaza and [[Sada, Shimane|Sada]].
==Environmental investigation== In October 2013 Japanese officials entered the base with US permission to look for buried cultural properties. They discovered dozens of abandoned metal drums, but did not report this to the [[Ginowan, Okinawa|Ginowan city]]'s mayor until March 2014. Members of the [[Ministry of Defense (Japan)|Japanese defense ministry's]] local bureau and Ginowan city visually inspected the site, as part of its cultural property research and "no unusual odor or color change in soil" was detected. Also apparently no health problems have been actively "reported by residents living around the base". Ginowan city government had called the Japanese defense ministry's to investigate for "possible environmental impacts". The Japanese Defense Minister [[Itsunori Onodera]] said: "We will take appropriate measures in cooperation with the United States and the city of Ginowan" as they plan environmental studies on soil in the week of March 18, 2014. The United States rarely allow environmental inspections on U.S. bases not planned for return to Japan.<ref>{{cite news|title=Japan to inspect soil at U.S. base in Okinawa for contamination |url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/kyodo-news-international/140314/japan-inspect-soil-at-us-base-okinawa-contamination |accessdate=16 March 2014 |newspaper=Kyodo News International |date=14 March 2014 |agency=2014 GlobalPost – International News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140316042256/http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/kyodo-news-international/140314/japan-inspect-soil-at-us-base-okinawa-contamination |archivedate=16 March 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==Land Return== The Futenma housing area of the base originally was to be returned to Japan between 2001 and 2003, 5–7 years from 1996.<ref>{{cite news|title=Japan set dates for handing back six bases|url=http://www.japanupdate.com/2013/04/u-s-japan-set-dates-for-handing-back-six-bases/|accessdate=20 September 2015|work=Japan Update.com|date=12 April 2013}}</ref> In 2006, the Nishi-Futenma housing area at Camp Foster was vacated and slated for return to Japan, but Japanese concerns of contamination stalled the transfer. For example, bungalows in the military housing area built in the 1950s were insulated with [[asbestos]]. Per the [[U.S.-Japan Status of Forces Agreement]] from 1960 the U.S military is not responsible for the remediation of land polluted by its bases in Japan. Because the central government has not challenged the dated agreement, the Okinawa Prefectural Assembly created its own special committee regarding U.S. bases, to collect information directly about past use and storage of chemicals. In October 2013 it created a department of pollution, which would circumvene the central government and its environmental investigations, which some believe are not interested in communicating the true levels of pollution.<ref name=jt1213>{{cite news|author1=Jon Mitchell|title=Pollution rife on Okinawa’s U.S.-returned base land|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/12/04/national/pollution-rife-on-okinawas-u-s-returned-base-land/#.Vf8BmH2Lrap|accessdate=20 September 2015|work=The Japan Times|date=4 December 2013}}</ref>
On 31 March 2015 the West Futenma housing area on Camp Foster was returned to Okinawa Prefecture implementating agreements to reduce and consolidate land used by the U.S. military. A 20-hectare part of the area is earmarked for a medical division with plans to build a prefecture administered advanced heavy particle cancer therapy facility. The University of the Ryukyus Faculty of Medicine, including the University Hospital, is also scheduled to move from its current location in Nishihara into a new facility to be constructed on the land.<ref>{{cite news|title=Part of Futenma housing area returned today|url=http://www.japanupdate.com/2015/03/part-of-futenma-housing-area-returns-to-okinawa-today/|accessdate=18 July 2015|newspaper=Stars and Stripes|date=31 March 2015|agency=2015 Stars and Stripes – International News}}</ref>
